73177.desc: Surveys the rapid development of genetic engineering science and biotechnology-based industries and examines the economic, health, environmental, legal, and social justice dimensions of new biotechnology applications: genetic screening, cloning, transgenic animals and crops, genetically engineered food, and biodiversity prospecting. Readings, lectures, World Wide Web site reviews, student presentations, and papers will address controversial choices faced now by scientists, farmers, doctors, consumers, public officials, and global governance agencies. Prerequisite(s): course 25 strongly recommended.

73178.desc: First course in intermediate sequence. Students review and expand upon their previous study of the language through short literary readings, vocabulary building, grammar study, composition, and discussions.

73179.desc: Introduction to major issues of method and critique in study of art and visual culture. Focuses on understanding disciplinary and critical modes of scholarly inquiry in the visual arts, including role of historical research. Emphasizes intensive reading, discussion, and writing.
73179.re: satisfaction of Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73180.desc: An introduction to the study of Latin American history from the Independence Wars in the early 19th century to the present. Topics include changing economic models of development, U.S. role, rural and urban life, women, nationalisms, populism, revolution, the military in politics, and the problem of democracy.

73181.desc: Surveys the history of East Asia from 1500 to 1894. Covers political, social, economic, and cultural histories of China, Japan, and Korea with the goal of perceiving a regional history that encompassed each society.

73182.desc: A survey of the economic, social, and political history of Europe from the era of the French Revolution to the outbreak of the first World War: 1789-1914. Course 70A is not prerequisite to 70B, nor 70B to 70C.

73183.desc: Explores the social, economic, cultural, and political development of British North America from the first European/Amerindian contacts in the late 16th century through the establishment of a provincial British colonial society. Course 110A is not a prerequisite to course 110B. (Formerly

73184.desc: Traces the history of immigration to the United States with emphasis on the 19th and early 20th centuries. Examines the causes and contexts of large-scale immigration; the similarities and differences in immigration and settlement patterns of different immigrant groups; how the process of immigration has been complicated by issues of race, ethnicity, gender, and class; and the ways in which U.S. immigration policy has influenced American's ideas of citizenship and freedom. (Formerly course 123).

73185.desc: Drawing on experiments in autobiography, the arts, and social theory, this course focuses on ideas and images of modernity in European culture. It also highlights the role of the intellectual as politically engaged or disillusioned witness in a violent century.

73186.desc: Examines Marx's use of his sources in political philosophy and political economy to develop a method for analyzing the variable ways in which social change is experienced as a basis for social action. Provides a similar analysis of contemporary materials. Contrasts and compares Marxian critiques of these materials and readings based on Nietzsche, psychoanalysis, cultural studies, and rational choice materialism.
73186.re: Enrollment restricted to legal studies majors during priority enrollment only.

73187.desc: Examines Marx's use of his sources in political philosophy and political economy to develop a method for analyzing the variable ways in which social change is experienced as a basis for social action. Provides a similar analysis of contemporary materials. Contrasts and compares Marxian critiques of these materials and readings based on Nietzsche, psychoanalysis, cultural studies, and rational choice materialism.
73187.re: Enrollment restricted to politics and Latin American and Latino studies/politics combined majors during priority enrollment only.

73188.desc: Examines variety of topics in constitutional law that are not covered in courses 111A and 111B. Focuses primarily on Supreme Court decisions and common-law debates.
73188.re: Enrollment restricted to legal studies majors during priority enrollment.

73189.desc: Introduction to how sounds pattern in grammars-why they vary, how they combine, etc. Emphasis is on developing theories to explain the patterns. Topics include distinctive feature theory, phonemic analysis, autosegmental phonology, and principles of syllabification and stress.
73189.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements, course 50.

73190.desc: A study of selected masterworks in relation to the periods which they represent. Emphasis upon the listening experience and awareness of musical style and structure. Illustrated lectures and directed listening.

73191.desc: Fundamentals of music and notation. Major, minor scales, intervals, triads, and inversions, root-position 7th chords, and the beginning harmonic analysis. Emphasis on the development of the ear and coordination. Exercises of pulse, rhythm, pitch, and coordination. Dictation and sight singing.
73191.re: Enrollment restricted to first-year students and sophomores; juniors and seniors admitted by permission of instructor.

73192.desc: Continuation of course 13. Triads and 7th chords and  their inversions. Introduces Church modes, melodic and harmonic analysis, four-part harmony, and keyboard harmony. Sight-singing, ear training, and dictation. Knowledge of musical notation and scales required. Students who wish to take this course and have not taken course 13 or the placement exam should consult the instructor. See the enrollment conditions section of the quarterly
73192.re: course 13 or music core curriculum placement exam. Prerequisite waived for non-UCSC students.

73193.desc: A study of correct reasoning, concentrating on developing the skills necessary to distinguish logically correct from logically incorrect arguments. The emphasis is on modern symbolic logic, although the traditional theory of the syllogism is also covered.

73194.desc: Current theories of the nature and preconditions of language, the nature of meaning, and the nature of truth.
73194.re: course 91 or 93 or 94; or consent of instructor. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73195.desc: Introduces key concepts in political discourse and key debates generated by contested terms such as "powers," "ideology," and "multiculturalism." Students read from canonical texts, feminist scholarship, historical materials, and contemporary cultural and postmodernist writings.

73196.desc: What does a citizen do? Uses political theory to answer this question as it relates to a number of issues, such as voting rights, diversity, gay marriage, and revolution. Draws on texts ranging from Aristotle to contemporary legal and cultural debates, to bear on the relationship of citizen action and identity. Other readings include Thoreau, Ellison, Rousseau, Marx, Arendt, and Socrates.

73197.desc: Upper-division introduction to international relations, international organizations, international political economy, foreign policy, conflict, and war. Explores a range of theories, issues and cases that are of interest to students of international affairs and are helpful in understanding recurring patterns of global conflict and cooperation. Addresses the nexus between domestic politics and the foreign policy of states.
73197.re: Enrollment restricted to politics and Latin American and Latino studies/politics combined majors during priority enrollment only.

73198.desc: Provides overview of U.S. foreign policy formulation: considers how U.S. political culture shapes foreign policy; examines governmental actors involved: the president, executive branch agencies, and Congress; then considers non-governmental actors: the media, interest groups, and public opinion. (Formerly
73198.re: Enrollment restricted to politics and politics/Latin American and Latino studies combined majors.

73199.desc: An overview of major personality theories from Freud to the modern day, and an introduction to contemporary personality research and assessment.
73199.re: course 1. Prerequisite waived for non-UCSC students.

73200.desc: A study of human sexuality emphasizing its psychological aspects. Sexual development, sexual orientations, biological influences, sexual attitudes and behavior, gender and gender roles, sex therapy, sexual coercion and abuse, sexually transmitted diseases, and the development of sexual relationships.

73201.desc: Focuses on individual and relational development from early adolescence into young adulthood. Emphasis on the mutual influences of family relationships and adolescent development, and on the interface of family, peer group, and school experience in cultural contexts.
73201.re: courses 3 and 10. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73202.desc: Cognition in children from infancy through adolescence. Basic and current research on children's understanding of the social and physical world. Focus on major theoretical perspectives: Piaget's constructivist approach, information processing approach, and sociocultural approach. (Formerly course 117.)
73202.re: courses 3 and 10. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73203.desc: Examines how social class shapes attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors. Emphasis is placed on structural barriers and their impact on the well-being of low-income groups. Strategies for reducing classist discrimination and improving interclass relations are discussed.
73203.re: Enrollment restricted to anthropology, community studies, economics, legal studies, politics, psychology, sociology, or feminist studies majors.

73204.desc: Covers field-adapted color illustration techniques including watercolor, colored pencil, inkwash, and mixed media. Field trips to various natural environments provide opportunities to sketch plants, mammals, birds, insects, landscapes, and other subject matter. In addition to in-class assignments, students produce a field sketchbook and a final project. Appropriate for students with demonstrated interest in science illustration through previous course work in science and art or through extracurricular activity in the field or a strong desire to learn the skills of the field. Enrollment process differs for Summer Session. May be repeated for credit.

73205.desc: With herbaria, live specimens, and field drawings as reference, students produce botanical images with both ink and watercolor. Basic plant morphology, dissection studies, and plant environments are introduced and integrated into illustration assignments. Appropriate for students with a demonstrated interest in science illustration through previous course work in science and art, or through extracurricular activity in the field, or a strong desire to learn the skills of the field. Enrollment process differs for Summer Session. May be repeated for credit.

73206.desc: Considers the role of popular music as a site of contemporary social practices and cultural politics. Examines the institutional organization and production of popular music, its cultural meanings, and its social uses by different communities and social formations. Also examines popular music as a vehicle through which major cultural and political debates about identity, sexuality, community, and politics are staged and performed.
73206.re: course 105A or 105B. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73207.desc: Focuses on the role feminist discourses play in cultural politics emphasizing sex, sexuality, and sex work as related to gender, race , and class. Examines the relationship between academic and popular feminisms. Interrogates post-feminism, third-wave feminism, and generational differences in feminisms. (Formerly

73208.desc: A healthy society requires a stable and sustainable relationship between society and nature. Covering past, present, and future, the course covers environmental history of the U.S., the variety and extent of environmental problems today, and explores their likely development in our lifetimes.

73209.desc: Explores social and cultural aspects of human sexuality and reproduction, including how and why meanings and behaviors are contested. Analyzes sexuality and reproduction as forms of social and political control as well as cultural expression and self-determination.

73210.desc: Major theories and concepts in sociological study of social psychology. Topics include identity and social interaction, deviance, sociology of emotions, social narratives, and the social construction of reality.

73211.desc: A survey of theories and systems of social stratification focusing on such phenomena as race, class, power, and prestige.
73211.re: Enrollment restricted to juniors and seniors.

73212.desc: Analyzes access to clean water, both in the American West and global South. Reviews water quality, pivotal role of water in settlement and society, history and contemporary inequalities, water supplies, international conflict over water, climate change, and human use of water.
73212.re: Enrollment restricted to juniors and seniors.

73213.desc: Advanced conversation and composition based on extensive readings in the humanities and social sciences. Students interested in this course who have not taken the prerequisite should meet with the instructor prior to the first class meeting.
73213.re: course 6, 56, Spanish for Spanish Speakers 63, or Spanish Placement Examination score of 70.

73214.desc: Explores Latin American culture through its cinematic art. Students are exposed to and participate in discussion, analysis, and commentary on important social, historical, and political issues presented in the films. Provides a greater understanding of Latin America, and works toward advanced communicative proficiency and comprehension of linguistic variations in countries such as Cuba, Argentina, México, Bolivia, Chile, and others. (Formerly
73214.re: course 6, 56, Spanish for Spanish Speakers 63, or Spanish Placement Examination score of 70.

73215.desc: This course explores writing genres within the natural sciences.  Emphasis is on the relationships between good science and good writing, clear thinking and clear writing.  Frequent papers and substantive revisions required.
73215.re: completion of 10 units coursework in the natural sciences, satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Enrollment restricted to juniors and seniors during priority enrollment.

73216.desc: Study of writing required in the selected professions, including law, politics, and government. Considers the rhetoric of each discipline and relevant texts. Includes lectures from visiting professionals and a series of writing assignments based on reading and research. Topic may vary from year to year, focusing on the rhetoric of other professional divisions: medicine, engineering, economics, and so forth.
73216.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements.

73217.desc: Introduces water-based screen printing. Students are introduced to processes including basic equipment, printing techniques, printing papers, stenciling processes, and photographic and digital techniques. Emphasis is on continued development of content and aesthetic awareness through the possibilities of screen printing. May be repeated for credit.

73218.desc: Course investigates the theory, history, and practice of pinhole photography. Students use self-made pinhole cameras of varying focal lengths and black and white paper negatives, film negatives, and transparencies. Emphasis on creative approach in both camera-making and image formation supported by advanced-level photographic techniques. Individual final portfolios.

73219.desc: An examination of invertebrates and their habitats. Lecture format. (Formerly Biology 136.)
73219.re: BIOL 20A, BIOE 20B, and BIOE 20C. BIOE 122L must be taken concurrently. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73220.desc: An examination of invertebrates and their habitats. Weekly laboratories or field trips. Students are billed a materials fee. (Formerly Biology 136L.)
73220.re: BIOL 20A, BIOE 20B, and BIOE 20C. BIOE 122 must be taken concurrently. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73221.desc: Principles and concepts underlying the function of tissues and organ systems in animals with emphasis on vertebrate systems. Students cannot receive credit for this course and BIOL 130. (Formerly Biology 131.)
73221.re: BIOL 20A, BIOE 20B, and BIOE 20C. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73223.desc: Focuses on physiological, behavioral, and population ecology, and on linking ecological processes to evolution. It includes basic principles, experimental approaches, concepts of modeling, and applications to ecological problems. (Formerly Biology 150.)

73224.desc: A survey of cetaceans, pinnipeds, sirenians, and sea otters, including natural history, systematics, physiology, behavior, anatomy, and conservation. (Formerly Biology 139.)
73224.re: BIOL 20A, BIOE 20B, and BIOE 20C; BIOL 110 is recommended.

73225.desc: Covers the basics of marine mammal taxonomy, anatomy, and field methods with an emphasis on local field identification and understanding of local species. Will include field trips to Long Marine Lab, Ano Nuevo, and Monterey Bay. Students are billed a materials fee. (Formerly Biology 139L.)
73225.re: BIOL 20A, BIOE 20B, and BIOE 20C. Must be taken concurrently with BIOE 129.

73226.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in courses 1B and 1C and important experimental techniques. Laboratory: 3 hours; lecture: 1-1/4 hours. Students are billed a materials fee. Course 1M offered in winter 2008 and spring2008 ; 1N offered in spring 2008 and fall 2008.
73226.re: course 1A. Concurrent enrollment in course 1B is required. Prerequisite waived for non-UCSC students.

73229.desc: Interdisciplinary introduction to the thought and experiences of lesbian, gay, bisexual, intersex, queer, and questioning (LGBTIQQ) studies. Interrogates queer identities and knowledges with empirical studies, philosophical treatises, political manifestos, novels, and films. Binaries such as gay/straight, male/female, man/woman, white/nonwhite, theory/experience are called into question to analyze the imbrications of sexuality, gender, race, and class.

73230.desc: Uses gendered historical analysis to examine sexuality, family, the body, and the nation-state in the U.S. since World War II. Primary source readings, advertisements, and film  used to investigate the intersection of race, class, and gender.

73231.desc: Analyzes the Latino experience in the U.S. with a special focus on strategies for economic and social empowerment. Stresses the multiplicity of the U.S. Latino community, drawing comparative lessons from Cuban-American, Puerto Rican, Chicano/Mexicano, and Central American patterns of economic participation and political mobilization.

73232.desc: Examines literature's relationship to the past and to the experience of history.

73233.desc: Acquaints students with the main stylistic features of modernism through the close reading of short stories by Sherwood Anderson, Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and William Faulkner. Through focusing on the individual texts, the cultural background is also taken into consideration. Satisfies the English and Modern Literature concentrations.

73234.desc: Teaches close reading and interpretation skills specific to poetry through examination of 20th-century English poetry. Satisfies the English and Modern Literary Studies concentrations; also satisfies the Poetry distribution requirement.

73235.desc: Evaluation of American national identity through the noir text (hard-boiled novels and film noir). Examines how these texts imagine America through representations of the urban "real." Satisfies the English and Modern Literary Studies concentrations.

73236.desc: Works by women from the 18th century to the present, with special attention to the relationship of literature to history, psychology, and aesthetics. Satisfies the English and Modern Literature concentrations.

73237.desc: Selected authors or issues in modern literary and cultural studies. Topics: (Summer) Classic Russian Novel; Satisfies the World and Modern Literature concentrations; also satisfies the Global and Senior Seminar distribution requirements. May be repeated for credit.
73237.re: Enrollment restricted to senior literature majors.

73238.desc: Topic for summer 2009: ancient Menippean satire and the Roman novel. Roman prose fiction�the ancient novel and texts from other genres�in relation to the history of the novel. Satisfies the Pre- and Early Modern Literature concentration; also satisfies the Pre- and Early Modern distribution requirement.

73239.desc: Analysis of formal narrative structures in Thomas More's

73240.desc: Examines the genre of travel writing and the critical and cultural issues it engages. Satisfies the Modern Literary Studies and World Literature concentrations; also satisfies the Global distribution requirement.

73241.desc: Demonstration of phenomena of classical and modern physics. Development of a familiarity with experimental methods. Special experimental projects may be undertaken by students in this laboratory.
73241.re: course 101A. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73242.desc: The first part of the course focuses on basic ethical, political, and logical issues in social scientific inquiry. The second part develops a wide range of skills and methods appropriate to actual research. Course 103A,
73242.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements; prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73245.desc: Introduction to basic acting skills and the problems of performance. Concentrates on expanding the students' range of expression and ability to respond to and analyze dramatic text. Students with little or no experience are encouraged to attend.

73246.desc: Approaches U.S. history by framing it in relation to world historical events and outcomes. Incorporates narratives of settlement and trade in Alaska, Hawaii, California, and the Southwest, connecting these regions to the British colonies and Atlantic World.

73247.desc: Engages the topic of embodiment within new media art theory and practice. Focus is on embodiment within performance, time-based, electronic, and new media arts practice. Students produce a final paper and artistic project on the topic. Lower-division undergraduates may enroll with permission of instructor.
73247.re: Enrollment restricted to juniors and seniors.

73248.desc: Promotes an ecological approach to design with an understanding of the environmental opportunities and constraints at play on the site and situation; works with the environment to maximize human comfort and energy efficiency.
73248.re: Enrollment restricted to environmental studies, environmental studies/biology, environmental studies/economics, and environmental studies/Earth and planetary sciences majors.

73249.desc: Style matters; it is powerful and always changing. Course is organized around a series of "Style Wars" that offer the chance to think about how any "style" is repeatedly used to ignite social, and not "simply aesthetic," change.

73250.desc: Introduces the general skills involved in writing in the social sciences as well as the particular demands of writing in sociology. Exposes students to the "inside" view of how good sociological writing is produced, ranging from contemporary sociologists'  reflections on their own best practices to C. Wright Mill's

73251.desc: Critical examination of the American healthcare system, its history, and the interests it serves; and an analysis of the healthcare systems of comparable nations.

73253.desc: Paradigms and designs in marine ecology.  A review of the paradigms that have shaped our understanding of marine ecology; analysis and discussion of experiments with these paradigms. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 208. (Formerly Biology 160.)
73253.re: BIOL 20A, BIOE 20B, and BIOE 20C; BIOE 107 or 140 recommended.

73254.desc: An examination of the history and mechanisms of evolutionary change. Topics include molecular evolution, natural and sexual selection, adaptation, speciation, biogeography, and macroevolution. (Formerly Biology 175.)
73254.re: BIOL 20A, BIOE 20B, BIOE 20C, and BIOL 105. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73255.desc: An introduction to social and reproductive behavior. Emphasis on studies of vertebrates in their natural habitat. Ideas concerning the evolution of social behavior, mating systems, and individual reproductive strategies. Case histories of well-studied animals that illustrate key principles in courtship and mating, parental behavior, and food-getting behavior. (Formerly Biology 140.)

73256.desc: Studies the effects of the Loma Prieta earthquake on the city of Santa Cruz, and results in an audio/photo installation. Uses the after effects of the earthquake to examine trauma, community, gentrification, and memory.

73257.desc: Surveys the victories, defeats, and ambiguous stalemates of disability-rights struggles in the past 50 years. Moves from empirical to theoretical understandings of disability. Multimedia curriculum incorporates video, audio, and new media.

73258.desc: Hands-on introduction to computer music. Students encounter a broad spectrum of technologies drawn from the history of electroacoustic music and apply them through regular programming/composition assignments. No previous experience with computer programming is assumed.

73259.desc: Analyzes politics and feminist studies to deepen understanding of how the U.S. war on crime has reshaped fundamental relations between states and citizens. Using a range of texts (film, legislation, government documents, legal decisions), examines the "war on crime" with emphasis on the politics of  "woman," gender, race, sexuality, and class in particular constructions of crime and criminality. Interrogates the meaning of rights within the republic and across its boundaries, both historically and in this neo-liberalizing moment.

73260.desc: Introduces the interdisciplinary field of transgender studies drawing on work in linked fields of feminist/women's studies and queer/sexuality studies. Addresses questions of conceptual and lived processes of gender, sex, and sexuality through and investigation of issues pertinent to transgender communities.

73261.desc: Introduces critical frameworks, methods, and problems in the field of black cultural studies, emphasizing work that addresses African American cultures. Seeks to foster a critical dialogue between relations of gender, race, and sexuality.

73262.desc: Seeks to: (1) develop in students a solid understanding of the skills needed for successful writing, including investigation, interpretation, and research; and (2) to develop these writing skills through an introduction to the politics of cultural memory in Latin America. Follows the struggles and contestation behind production of cultural memory in Latin America by centering race, gender, class, and sexuality in students' analysis. Considers the relationship between cultural memory and national/collective identity, social justice, museums, and performance.

73263.desc: Focuses on three intriguing topics that philosophers have considered when they have reflected on film. The course inquires about 1) the nature of film; 2) film and narration; and 3) the relationship between film and philosophy. Students examine these topics through readings from philosophers, film theorists, movie critics, and required screenings of films.

73264.desc: Exploration of the related concepts of value and meaning in the contemporary Western world and their relation to a technological mindset in terms of Nietzschean and Heideggerian interpretation. The word "technology" commonly signifies little more than sophisticated tools, but has a much deeper significance within the overall conception of ourselves and the world at large. Course touches on metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, culture, and language.

73265.desc: Explores philosopher Paul Woodruff's argument that the forgotten virtue of reverence is essential for a well-functioning society.

73266.desc: Explores the role of thought experiments, intuitions, and counterexamples in some central debates of contemporary philosophy.

73267.desc: Systematic investigation of the development of philosophical perspectives on sexuality from ancient times to the 21st century. Topics include prostitution, homosexuality, perversion, promiscuity/monogamy, pornography, feminism, and sexual morality.

73268.desc: Addresses issues relevant to many interdisciplinary currents, analyzing art, architecture, and several aspects of visual culture of the Italian Renaissance. Students examine instances where concepts and topics complement interdisciplinary issues of gender, sexuality, politics, and religion.

73269.desc: Explores how women artists intervene in the art world by representing themselves and their own work. Their projects and this course engage a range of critical debates about subjectivity, feminism, narrative, and representation. Participants study visual and textual genres, such as women's self-portraiture, performance art, artist statements, visual-textual hybrid projects, and scholarly texts.

73270.desc: Course will focus on understanding human genes. Accessible to non-science majors. Will cover principles of human inheritance and techniques used in gene analysis. The evolutionary, social, ethical, and legal issues associated with knowledge of the human genome will be discussed.

73271.desc: Experiments conducted with primary focus on quantitative physiological principles of organ systems and intact organisms. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 130L. Students are billed a materials fee. (Formerly Biology 131L.)
73271.re: courses 20A, 20B, and 20C. Concurrent enrollment in course 131 is required. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73272.desc: Ubiquitous computing integrates computer and communication technology with day-to-day life. Ubiquitous and mobile technology includes: MP-3 players, camera cell phones, Bluetooth headsets, sensor networks, and new emerging technologies. Course provides an overview of the technology and economics of ubiquitous computing.

73273.desc: A sustained inquiry into the social, political, economic, and historical foundations of schools with an emphasis on community attitudes toward education. Student narratives of engagement and resistance will provide a basis for insights and interventions useful to educators. (Formerly course 281.)

73274.desc: Reviews issues of literacy and writing in secondary content areas. Students write in several genre and prepare lesson plans for teaching writing within the discourse of their respective curricular area.
73274.re: Concurrent enrollment in course 225 is required; enrollment restricted to education graduate students.

73275.desc: Provides a theoretical and practical foundation for teaching reading within content area instruction in middle school and secondary classrooms.  Field experiences and interactive instruction will facilitate learning about strategies, curricula, methods, materials, and observation. Intended for students pursuing a single subject credential. (Formerly course 211B.)

73277.desc: A brief description of the relevant chemical and physical properties of the main classes of foods, vitamins, and minerals. Discussion of their digestion, sources, metabolism, recommended daily allowances, and effects of deficiencies. High school chemistry strongly recommended as preparation.

73278.desc: Required for master's students in education. Three basic units comprise the subject matter: teaching/learning, with such topics as development, learning, pedagogy, and socialization theories; schooling, as the context of teaching/learning both in its existent structures and its reform movements; and the sociocultural context in which educational institutions exist, including topics such as cultural and historical forces, political and economic conditions, family, and community structures.

73279.desc: Required for master's students in education. Three basic units comprise the subject matter: teaching/learning, with such topics as development, learning, pedagogy, and socialization theories; schooling, as the context of teaching/learning both in its existent structures and its reform movements; and the sociocultural context in which educational institutions exist, including topics such as cultural and historical forces, political and economic conditions, family, and community structures.

73280.desc: Required for master's students in education. Three basic units comprise the subject matter: teaching/learning, with such topics as development, learning, pedagogy, and socialization theories; schooling, as the context of teaching/learning both in its existent structures and its reform movements; and the sociocultural context in which educational institutions exist, including topics such as cultural and historical forces, political and economic conditions, family, and community structures.

73281.desc: Required for master's students in education. Three basic units comprise the subject matter: teaching/learning, with such topics as development, learning, pedagogy, and socialization theories; schooling, as the context of teaching/learning both in its existent structures and its reform movements; and the sociocultural context in which educational institutions exist, including topics such as cultural and historical forces, political and economic conditions, family, and community structures.

73282.desc: Explores the practical application of teaching and learning writing in elementary school classrooms, and considers the theoretical ideas that underpin these current practices. Guest teachers speak about their own inquiries, challenges, and successes in teaching writing.

73283.desc: Explores the practical application of teaching and learning writing in elementary school classrooms, and considers the theoretical ideas that underpin these current practices. Guest teachers speak about their own inquiries, challenges, and successes in teaching writing.

73284.desc: This course is required for prospective teachers. It provides an overview of the use of technology in the K–12 classroom. Topics covered include using the Internet and the web, building a web page, and using resources for educators on the web. Students will review software applications in a particular content area, use technology to develop lesson plans, and create integrated, thematic curricula in which technology is utilized to promote higher-order thinking, creativity, and problem-solving. (Formerly course 220.)
73284.re: Enrollment restricted to graduate students admitted to the credential program.

73285.desc: This course is required for prospective teachers. It provides an overview of the use of technology in the K–12 classroom. Topics covered include using the Internet and the web, building a web page, and using resources for educators on the web. Students will review software applications in a particular content area, use technology to develop lesson plans, and create integrated, thematic curricula in which technology is utilized to promote higher-order thinking, creativity, and problem-solving. (Formerly course 220.)
73285.re: Enrollment restricted to graduate students admitted to the credential program.

73286.desc: Laboratory sequence in assembly language programming. The basics of logic design, both RISC and microcontroller programming. May include C language programming. Two two-hour laboratories per week .
73286.re: course 3 or 8, or Computer Science 10 or 12A  or 5C or 5J or 5P, or Biomolecular Engineering 60, or suitable programming experience; previous or concurrent enrollment in course 12 required.

73287.desc: Provides biology majors with the theory and practice of experimental biology. A wide range of concepts and techniques used in the modern laboratory are included in the exercises. Designed to satisfy the introductory biology lab requirement of many medical and professional schools. Students are billed a materials fee.
73287.re: BIOL 20A and previous or concurrent enrollment in BIOE 20B. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

73290.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 6C. One three-hour laboratory session per week.
73290.re: courses 6A/L or 5A/L; concurrent enrollment in course 6C required; courses 6B/M are suggested.

73291.desc: Explores science illustration relating to marine subjects and their environment, using watercolor and mixed-media techniques. Current illustration styles and conventions are covered, emphasizing making marine science accessible to everyone. No prior art or science experience necessary.

73292.desc: Origins and development of international law: international law is examined both as a reflection of the present world order and as a basis for transformation. Topics include jurisdiction and sovereignty, treaties, use of force, commercial law, and human rights.
73292.re: Enrollment restricted to legal studies majors during priority enrollment.

73296.desc: Introduces water-based screen printing. Students are introduced to processes including basic equipment, printing techniques, printing papers, stenciling processes, and photographic and digital techniques. Emphasis is on continued development of content and aesthetic awareness through the possibilities of screen printing. May be repeated for credit.

73299.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 6A. One three-hour laboratory session per week.

73306.desc: Hands-on introduction to computer music. Students encounter a broad spectrum of technologies drawn from the history of electroacoustic music and apply them through regular programming/composition assignments. No previous experience with computer programming is assumed.

73344.desc: Thesis research conducted under faculty supervision. Although the course may be repeated for credit, not every degree program will accept a repeated course toward degree requirements. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.
